poem:
**Fusion at Osteria Angelina**

In the East of London,  
Italian meets Japan—  
a dance of flavors,  
where spaghetti meets sashimi,  
pasta embraces miso's whisper.  
Chopsticks and forks  
clink softly,  
as cultures twirl—  
in the heart of Spitalfields,  
upon this plate—  
a new sonnet sings,  
with Zafferano dreams.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Osteria Angelina, London E1: ‘There’s a lot to adore’ – restaurant review | Grace Dent on restaurants One undeniable fact about Angelina, which has just opened a second site in Spitalfields, east London, is that in the now mini-group’s relatively short existence, they’ve singlehandedly made the phrase “Italian-Japanese restaurant” seem a much more normal thing to say. Patently, Angelina Mark 1 over in Dalston was not the first time in culinary history that Milan met". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
